title: Demand for Property in London Spiked This Summer, But Prices Still Lag
text:
Demand for property across London’s prime neighborhoods reached its highest level in more than a decade this summer, according to a report Friday from Knight Frank.



For every new property listing to hit the market there were 11.4 new prospective buyers in August.



More: For Foreign House Hunters in London, the Time to Act Is Now

With such a high number of potential buyers, the amount of viewings rose over the summer, too, reaching its highest point in more than five years across July and August.



There were 16% more viewings over the two-month period compared to the same time last year, as buyers respond to price adjustments and, in the case of overseas buyers, the weakness of the pound, the London-based brokerage and property consultants said.



The increasing demand “reflects the fact that while many buyers are primed to transact, the political uncertainty has caused some potential vendors to hesitate,” Tom Bill, Knight Frank’s head of London residential research, wrote in the report.



Despite the Brexit uncertainty, and the hesitation of some potential buyers to make moves, the number of transactions in prime central London rose 13% in the six months to August, compared to the same period last year. The increase was another recent high point, marking the highest figure over the equivalent period since 2014.

But price growth has yet to turn positive in the city.



In prime central London prices fell 3.9% annually in August.



The priciest of homes are continuing to fare better than their more affordable counterparts. While homes in the capital valued at above £10 million (US$12.3 million) saw prices decline 2.9% in the year to August, the decrease was the smallest seen by any other price bracket.



In comparison, the drop for homes valued below £1 million was highest, falling 4.9% in the same time.
